Class SLView

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.awt.Component
      • java.awt.Container
        • java.awt.Window
          • java.awt.Frame
            • javax.swing.JFrame
              • SLView
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.awt.image.ImageObserver, java.awt.MenuContainer, java.io.Serializable, javax.accessibility.Accessible, javax.swing.RootPaneContainer, javax.swing.WindowConstants

    public class SLView
extends javax.swing.JFrame
    SLView defines a GUI interface that can be used as a user interface for a variety of programs.

    This is the "view" component of a model-view-controller (MVC) design pattern. The view object interacts with a controller, which should be registered via the registerController method.

    The graphical interface includes the following panels:

    1) A grid of buttons can be used for game playing (checkers, etc.)

    2) A multi-line text area is provided for output,

    3) A text field and up to two buttons can be used to input and process user input strings,

    4) Four cursor buttons can be programmed to perform special tasks.

    5) Four command buttons can be programmed for any purpose, and

    6) A text field that triggers an action method when the user presses ENTER.

    Non-grid buttons can be enabled/disabled and set visible or not. They can also be renamed. Each button and the text field (panel 5) have associated action methods that are invoked when the user presses a button or types text followed by ENTER in panel 6. Panels 3-5 can be set visible or not. Panel 1 is only created if the second constructor is used. There is no method for making the grid buttons invisible once created.

    2014 (version 2) IMPORTANT NOTE: The button grid looks like a proper grid under Java 7. If Java 6 is used, the grid may appear as buttons with a little space between each. The program still works under 6, but the appearance of the grid will not be optimal.

    2014 (version 2.2) The SLView constructor that sets the button grid now includes four parameters for dimensions: ( title_string, number of rows, number of columns, button width, button height)

    2014 (version 2.3) The SLView object defined in SLView.main() was changed from "adv" to "main" so that copying code from the class (the code is typically used to prototype the view) to Main.main() does not require refactoring due to having two variables, "adv" and "main".

    Author:
    Pierre von Kaenel
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

      • SLView

        public SLView(java.lang.String title,
      int row,
      int col,
      int x,
      int y)
        This constructor includes a button grid.
        Parameters:
        title - for the window
        row - Number of rows in the grid (e.g. 3 rows are numbered 0, 1, 2).
        col - Number of columns in the grid (first column is column 0)
        x - Grid button's width
        y - Grid button's height

      • appendTextArea

        public void appendTextArea(java.lang.Object s)
        Append text to the text area. Use "\n" to insert new line.
        Parameters:

      • getTextArea

        public java.lang.String getTextArea()
        Get the text currently displayed in the text area. Does not affect displayed text.
        Returns:
        the String displayed in the text area.

      • getABInputText

        public java.lang.String getABInputText()
        Get the user's input from the "ab" text input line. This method could be called when the user presses one of the a-b buttons to process the text. When called, the text is deleted from the text field.
        Returns:
        the user's input text. Return "" if none has been entered.

      • setABTextInput

        public void setABTextInput(java.lang.String s)
        Display text in the textInput field
        Parameters:
        s - the text to display

      • terminate

        public void terminate()

      • registerController

        public void registerController(SLController c)
        In MVC, a controller is needed to manipulate this view object. The controller should be instantiated as a subclass of SLController and passed to the view using this method. main() could also call this to set up the links between model, view, and controller.
        Parameters:
        c - a subclass of SLController

      • setGridButtonText

        public void setGridButtonText(java.lang.String str,
                     int row,
                     int col)
        Write a String to a button on the button grid.
        Parameters:
        str - to display on the button
        row - of button in the grid (starting with offset 0)
        column - of button in the grid (starting with offset 0)

      • getGridButtonText

        public java.lang.String getGridButtonText(int row,
                                 int col)
        Get the text currently written on the button.
        Parameters:
        row - of button in the grid (starting with offset 0)
        column - of button in the grid (starting with offset 0)
        Returns:
        the string on the button, or the empty string, "", if button grid is not used.

      • setGridButtonForeground

        public void setGridButtonForeground(java.awt.Color color,
                           int row,
                           int col)
        Set the Foreground color of a button on the button grid.
        Parameters:
        color - of the text on the button
        row - of button in the grid (starting with offset 0)
        column - of button in the grid (starting with offset 0)

      • getGridButtonForeground

        public java.awt.Color getGridButtonForeground(int row,
                                     int col)
        Return the Color of the text on the button. (Note: some platforms do not permit changing a button color, hence this feature is not provided.)
        Parameters:
        row - of the button in the grid
        col - of the button in the grid
        Returns:
        the Color of the text, or nul if the button grid is not used.

      • main

        public static void main(java.lang.String[] args)
        A demo program that just displays the GUI. Do not use this method as the main() for a project that uses the MVC library. Consider defining the main() method in another class, such as Main.
